user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of answer_unique_tiny_response:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
answer_unique_tiny_response (void *cls,
                             struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                             const char *url,
                             const char *method,
                             const char *version,
                             const char *upload_data,
                             size_t *upload_data_size,
                             void **req_cls)
{
  static int marker = 0;
  struct MHD_Response *r;
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  (void) cls;  /* Unused */
  (void) url; (void) version; /* Unused */
  (void) upload_data; (void) upload_data_size; /* Unused */

  if (NULL == *req_cls)
  {
    /* The fist call */
    *req_cls = (void *) ▮
    /* Do not send reply yet. No error. */
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */

#if MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (tiny_body),
                                              tiny_body);
#else  /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (tiny_body),
                                       (void *) tiny_body,
                                       MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT);
#endif /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection, MHD_HTTP_OK, r);
  MHD_destroy_response (r);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
#if MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (tiny_body),
                                              tiny_body);
#else  /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (tiny_body),
                                       (void *) tiny_body,
                                       MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT);
#endif /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */

if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */
explanation: Other code in the function does not appear to contain statically unreachable statements and therefore does not need investigation for Rule 2.1: - The (void) casts for unused parameters and the static declaration of marker are simple declarations/expressions and are always reachable/used for their intended purpose. - The response-queueing sequence (MHD_queue_response, MHD_destroy_response, return ret) is reachable when *req_cls is non-NULL and the method is GET or HEAD; these are normal, intended control paths. - The early returns in the listed fragments are control-flow decisions that deliberately short-circuit processing (first-call handling and unsupported-method handling) rather than dead code; they are flagged above because they cause other code to be unreachable in those specific invocation cases and thus warrant review. - There are no obvious syntactically dead statements (code after an unconditional return in the same block) other than the early-return fragments already listed. Therefore only the listed fragments require further investigation for potential unreachable-code issues under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.
